feed.title: Amrita Kundu
feed.subtitle: This is the official portfolio of Amrita Kundu.

entry.title: Silk Threads- Is silk making a dying art?

link.title: Silk Threads- Is silk making a dying art?

entry.content:
The documentary Silk Threads was filmed in a town called Sujapur in West Bengal, India that is known for producing silk and cotton threads. Silk Threads tells the story of how silk is being made from scratch. The focus here is on the artisans who separate the silk threads from the cocoons and turn them into beautiful silk yarns. The first half of the documentary focuses on the silk making process whereas the later half sheds light on the lives of the artisans and ponders over the question whether silk making will end up becoming a dying art.

Click here to watch the documentary
entry.summary: The documentary Silk Threads was filmed in a town called Sujapur in West Bengal, India that is known for producing silk and cotton threads. Silk Threads tells the story of how silk is being made from scratch. The focus here is on the artisans who separate the silk threads from the cocoons and turn them into beautiful silk yarns. The first half of the documentary focuses on the silk making process whereas the later half sheds light on the lives of the artisans and ponders over the question whether silk making will end up becoming a dying art.

entry.title: Crafts from Andhra Pradesh and Telangana- Kalamkari, Pochampally, Mangalgiri

link.title: Crafts from Andhra Pradesh and Telangana- Kalamkari, Pochampally, Mangalgiri

entry.content:
This film focuses on crafts from three different regions of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana. The journey starts from Pedana in Andhra Pradesh which is known for its Kalamkari prints. The entire process of screen printing of Kalamkari using wooden blocks and colours is shown here. The second part of the film takes you to Pochampally in Telangana where it is shown how silk saree is woven using the traditional tie and dye method. The cotton saree weaving of Mangalgiri is shown in the final part where the weavers let you in about the hurdles faced by the weaving community.

Click here to watch the documentary
entry.summary: This film focuses on crafts from three different regions of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana. The journey starts from Pedana in Andhra Pradesh which is known for its Kalamkari prints. The entire process of screen printing of Kalamkari using wooden blocks and colours is shown here. The second part of the film takes you to Pochampally in Telangana where it is shown how silk saree is woven using the traditional tie and dye method. The cotton saree weaving of Mangalgiri is shown in the final part where the weavers let you in about the hurdles faced by the weaving community.

entry.title: Lucknow Chikan- Traditional hand embroidery from Lucknow

link.title: Lucknow Chikan- Traditional hand embroidery from Lucknow

entry.content:
This film takes you directly to the origins of the chikankari work. It shows the working conditions of the embroiders and the limitations that they have been facing. The film tries to find out how the work that once had its foothold in Lucknow is going to survive with the changing tides. Shot entirely in Lucknow, this film shows the process of chikankari work from the time the patterns were compiled on butter papers, to being printed on plain clothes, the embroidery work and at last the final wash at Gomti river before being shipped to the markets.

Click here to watch the documentary
entry.summary: This film takes you directly to the origins of the chikankari work. It shows the working conditions of the embroiders and the limitations that they have been facing. The film tries to find out how the work that once had its foothold in Lucknow is going to survive with the changing tides. entry.title: Bengal Sultanate- Monuments from the bygone era

link.title: Bengal Sultanate- Monuments from the bygone era

entry.content:
This documentary showcases eleven monuments from the Bengal Sultanate that are now present in Pandua and Gaur in India. The film starts with a brief history about the timeline of the various dynasties that ruled the Bengal Sultanate and then delves into what each monument has to offer. With terracotta work on walls and arabic inscriptions and Mihrabs in mosques, the monuments that are nestled in interior Bengal are a perfect mix of indigenous and islamic architecture. The monuments today represent the architectural legacy of the Bengal Sultanate.

Click here to watch the documentary
entry.summary: This documentary showcases eleven monuments from the Bengal Sultanate that are now present in Pandua and Gaur in India. The film starts with a brief history about the timeline of the various dynasties that ruled the Bengal Sultanate and then delves into what each monument has to offer. With terracotta work on walls and arabic inscriptions and Mihrabs in mosques, the monuments that are nestled in interior Bengal are a perfect mix of indigenous and islamic architecture. The monuments today represent the architectural legacy of the Bengal Sultanate.

entry.title: Taant Tale- Cotton sarees of Bengal

link.title: Taant Tale- Cotton sarees of Bengal

entry.content:
This film can alternatively be called ‘The eight steps of making taant sarees’ as it shows the step-by-step process of making taant or cotton sarees. It shows how the cotton is first made into bundles using both the traditional and modern spinning wheels, then the dying of the cotton bundles, weaving of sarees and it also talks about the experience of the weavers.

Click here to watch the documentary
entry.summary: This film can alternatively be called ‘The eight steps of making taant sarees’ as it shows the step-by-step process of making taant or cotton sarees. It shows how the cotton is first made into bundles using both the traditional and modern spinning wheels, then the dying of the cotton bundles, weaving of sarees and it also talks about the experience of the weavers.

entry.title: Maatir Protima- Hands that make idols of clay

link.title: Maatir Protima- Hands that make idols of clay

entry.content:
There is round-the-year work for the sculptors who are engaged in making the clay idols or maatir protima. The protimas that we see at the festivals or at temples are painted and are adorned with bright coloured clothes, jewellery and in many cases, hold weapons as well. But before all this, the sculptors collect the maati, that is the clay from riverbanks and apply it on the hay models of the protimas that they have already prepared. Unlike other traditional art works, many youngsters are occupied in this line of work and find the work of hands fulfilling.

Click here to watch the documentary

But before all this, the sculptors collect the maati, that is the clay from riverbanks and apply it on the hay models of the protimas that they have already prepared. Unlike other traditional art works, many youngsters are occupied in this line of work and find the work of hands fulfilling.
